attributes.action: Increase maintenance loan for final year university students due to COVID
attributes.background: Students about to start their final year of university have found out that they're going to get less maintenance loan due to not being considered students during summer. attributes.additional_details:
Student accommodation is expensive - the cheapest accommodation from private providers such as Portland Green can often cost as much as £396 a month (https://bit.ly/35gqcyB).

A lot of the part-time industries that students normally work in have been dramatically affected as a result of the pandemic (common student part-time jobs cited here https://bit.ly/2Tu4vs2) 

The average student income can't cover the cheapest provider cited above for more than three months (https://bit.ly/3wnmlLP).

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about the amount of maintenance loans, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do. It's not clear how much you want maintenance loans to be increased by, or if you want rules relating to the different amount of maintenance loan available to students living at home as compared to away from home to be changed.

It's also not clear what you mean when you say maintenance loans will be reduced because students aren't being regarded as students this summer. The Student Loans Company has published guidance for students who have moved back home in the January term: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/guidance-for-students-who-have-moved-back-home-in-the-january-term

Further, the Government's Housing Infrastructure Fund was specifically created to support the building of the infrastructure needed to support the building of new houses, potentially including roads, sewage and more: https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/government/uploads/system/uploads/attachment_data/file/625528/DCLG_Introduction_to_Housing_Infrastructure_WEB.pdf. It is therefore not clear what else you want the UK Government to do. 

You could start a petition calling for the Government to ban any development on green belt land if that is something you'd like to happen.

rejection.details:
We can't accept your petition because the UK Government and Parliament aren't responsible for the issue you raise. Local planning issues are the responsibility of your local council.

You could raise your issue with a local councillor who represents you. You can use this page to find out who your local councillors are, and how to contact them:

https://www.gov.uk/find-your-local-councillors

Calling-in a planning decision

Once an application is made for the development to take place, all local residents have the right to request that a planning application be ‘called in’ by the Department for Housing, Communities and Local Government. This means that it will assess the planning application against certain criteria and decide if a full inquiry is needed. For more information, including the criteria and how to request the call in of a planning application, see:
 
http://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/SN00930/SN00930.pdf 

You could also contact your local MP, who may wish to request the decision is called in if they agree with you. You can use this page to find out who your local MP is and how to contact them:
 
http://www.parliament.uk/mps-lords-and-offices/mps/ 


If you want the UK Government or Parliament to take action, for example to amend the legislation and policy framework which governs planning and development decisions taken by local authorities, you could start a new petition specifically asking for that action.

attributes.action: Make it compulsory for food manufacturers to list all Legumes as an allergen.
attributes.background: I want legumes to be listed on food packaging as an allergen. Very often legumes are used and are called something else. For example 'Gram Flour' is in fact Chickpeas. Manufacturers need to be more transparent. A legume allergy can be just as life threatening as a peanut allergy.
attributes.additional_details:
I believe people with a legume allergy should be able to look at the list of ingredients on food packaging and be able to EASILY see if the product contains something which may cause them to have a severe allergic reaction. 

Manufacturers should not be able to change the name of ingredients. 

Legumes include some of the following;

Lentils
Chickpeas 
Green Peas
Pinto Beans
Mange-Tout
Tamarind 
Butter Beans

And many more.....

attributes.action: Use the Green New Deal to rebuild the economy after the COVID19 crisis/recession
attributes.background:
Make the Green New Deal the model to rebuild the UK economy after this crisis.
Lead the world, ahead of COP26, & use this time to create a low-carbon economy that protects against future & larger crises caused by climate breakdown.
Create millions of jobs in green sectors that lead to a 2°C world.
attributes.additional_details:
COVID19 demonstrates the fragility of society in times of crisis. Climate change, through food insecurity, water scarcity, climate refugees etc., will create similar but larger crises in the near future. 

The previous economic system guaranteed an increase in global temperatures to well above 2°C. Scientists show +2°C is the last point of safety.

COVID-19 shows we can make huge economic & social changes in times of crisis, but the bigger, climate crisis is still ahead. We must change path now.

attributes.action: Ban plastic greenwashing in the homecare category
attributes.background: Many homecare brands promote their refillable products as eco-friendly, but omit that they are packaged in plastic that will likely not be recycled. We want a ban on this greenwashing and a mandate for brands to disclose what really happens to their packaging & what they do to minimise plastic usage
attributes.additional_details: The UK’s 27.8 million households each use an average of 25 cleaning bottles a year, that’s 50,000 tonnes of plastic. Although the government claims that almost half of UK’s plastic packaging gets recycled, in reality it's less than 10%. Meanwhile, consumers are unaware that most of their 'recyclable' plastic packing will end up in incinerators and landfills. A ban on plastic greenwashing and more transparency around recycling is needed to enable consumers to make better informed, green choices.

rejection.details:
We understand that you would like manufacturers to make clear to customers about which of their products are recycled, but we're not what information you'd like them to disclose to customers and how you would like them to do it. Whether and where products are recycled by customers is a personal decision for them based on which materials their local authority will accept as recyclable, not the UK Government or Parliament.

We have published the following petition, which you might like to sign:

Create laws for what can/cant be classed as sustainable to prevent greenwashing:
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/591674
